sentence.Network_en: Mona remains unshaken by her ordeal and is matter-of-fact about her courage.
sentence.Network_cn: 莫娜不为她经历的这场磨难所动，对自己表现出的勇气也态度淡然。

sentence.Network_en: The former hostage is in remarkably good shape considering his ordeal.
sentence.Network_cn: 想想人质曾遭受的折磨，获救后其身体状况已经是出奇地好了。

sentence.Network_en: Stopping only briefly to regain her composure, she described her agonising ordeal.
sentence.Network_cn: 她只停顿了一小会儿让自己恢复平静，然后讲述了她无比痛苦的经历。

随身英语听力:英国最大... ... got the better of (某某)战胜了（某某） traumatic ordeal 让人精神受创的经历 tucking in 尽情的吃.

derivation.yuyuan_name: Old English ordāl, ordēl, of Germanic origin; related to German urteilen 'give judgement', from a base meaning 'share out'. The word is not found in Middle English (except once in Chaucer's Troylus); modern use of sense 2 began in the late 16th cent., whence sense 1 (mid 17th cent.)

encyclopedia.content: 神判 ordeal 借助神的力量，为定夺诉讼纷争之输赢或确定罪犯，而对当事人或嫌疑者施行考验的原始审判方式。神明裁判的简称。曾存在于世界许多民族中。中世纪流行于欧洲的决斗亦源于此。那时候，人们认为神力可以对人世间的是非作出判定，并帮助人们给罪犯量刑。其方式多种多样，常用的有 ：吞食某种有毒的东西、手下油锅取物、决斗、将嫌疑者投入河中，等等。以被考验者能否顺利通过考验来定输赢或判明当事人是否有罪。

entry.def: If you describe an experience or situation as an ordeal, you think it is difficult and unpleasant.

example.ex: ...the painful ordeal of the last eight months...

example.tran: 她描述了自己备受折磨的苦难经历。

means.word_mean: 2. a primitive method of determining a person's guilt or innocence by subjecting the accused person to dangerous or painful tests believed to be under divine control; escape was usually taken as a sign of innocence

auth_sentence.content: The ordeal, however, was taking its toll.

Sentence.sentence: Back in the good old days—say, two years ago, when the last of my children suffered the ordeal (折磨)—a high-school student applying to college could procrastinate all the way to New Year's Day of their senior year, assuming they could withstand the parental pestering (烦扰).

sentences.en: Being lost in the wilderness for a week was an ordeal for me.
sentences.cn: 在荒野里迷路一星期对我来说真是一场磨难。
